sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: detect log.dat of remcos and registry entry

Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.
Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are
used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to
load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.
Detects modifications to the Windows Defender configuration settings using PowerShell to add exclusions
Detects modification of autostart extensibility point (ASEP) in registry.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Victor Sergeev, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, Gleb Sukhodolskiy, Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community, Tim Shelton, frack113 (split)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET DROP Spamhaus DROP Listed Traffic Inbound group 8
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert ip [77.91.68.0/24,77.91.76.0/24,77.91.124.0/24,77.105.132.0/24,77.105.163.0/24,78.40.143.0/24,79.110.22.0/24,79.110.49.0/24,79.110.62.0/24,79.137.192.0/24,80.64.30.0/24,80.66.75.0/24,80.66.77.0/24,80.76.49.0/24,80.94.92.0/24,80.94.95.0/24,80.208.192.0/20,80.244.11.0/24,81.94.150.0/24,81.94.159.0/24] any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"ET DROP Spamhaus DROP Listed Traffic Inbound group 8"; reference:url,www.spamhaus.org/drop/drop.txt; threshold: type limit, track by_src, seconds 3600, count 1; classtype:misc-attack; flowbits:set,ET.Evil; flowbits:set,ET.DROPIP; sid:2400007; rev:4114; metadata:affected_product Any, attack_target Any, deployment Perimeter, tag Dshield, signature_severity Minor, created_at 2010_12_30, updated_at 2024_09_27;)
alert ( gid:119; sid:279; rev:1; msg:"(http_inspect) invalid status line"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO Windows Powershell User-Agent Usage"; flow:established,to_server; http.user_agent; content:"Mozilla/"; startswith; content:") WindowsPowerShell/"; distance:0; fast_pattern; classtype:not-suspicious; sid:2033355; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2021_07_16, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2021_07_16;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO DNS Redirection Service Domain in DNS Lookup (con-ip .com)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert dns $HOME_NET any -> any any (msg:"ET INFO DNS Redirection Service Domain in DNS Lookup (con-ip .com)"; dns.query; dotprefix; content:".con-ip.com"; nocase; endswith; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2037787; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2022_07_19, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2022_07_19;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity MEDIUM because it was considered trojan.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided PowerShell code exhibits several characteristics typical of malicious behavior. It begins by defining a function `XOR-Crypt`, which takes a file path and a byte key as parameters to perform an XOR encryption on the contents of the specified file. This is often used in malware to obfuscate payloads, making them harder to detect by security software.

Next, the code defines a `Download-File` function that attempts to download a file from a specified URL and save it to a designated location. The URL points to a potentially harmful file named "love.kernel". After downloading this file, the script applies the `XOR-Crypt` function to it, further obscuring its content.

The script then creates a directory under `C:\Windows\System32\FrameNET8.0.6\`, which is a common tactic used by malware to hide itself within system directories. It adds this directory to Windows Defender's exclusion list, preventing detection by antivirus software.

Following this, the downloaded file is renamed to "NET-Framework.exe", which could mislead users or security tools into thinking it is a legitimate application. The script generates a Visual Basic Script (VBS) file and a batch file (BAT) designed to execute the renamed executable silently in the background without user interaction.

Finally, the script modifies the Windows registry to change the `Userinit` value, which controls what processes run when a user logs in. By adding the BAT file to this key, the malware ensures that it will execute every time the system starts, establishing persistence.

Overall, the combination of file download, encryption, renaming, and registry modification indicates that this code is designed to install and execute malicious software while evading detection.

The code defines two functions: `XOR-Crypt` and `Download-File`.  `XOR-Crypt` takes a file path and a byte as input and performs a bitwise XOR operation on each byte of the file using the provided key, overwriting the original file. `Download-File` downloads a file from a specified URL to a given destination.

The script then creates a directory at "C:\Windows\System32\FrameNET8.0.6\", adds this directory as an exclusion path for Windows Defender, downloads a file ("love.kernel") from "http://api.g3ll3rt.com/wxqlkjwqrikqwfr1/wjzgfe1132x40wxf/user2/love.kernel" to this directory, XOR-crypts the downloaded file with key 219, renames it to "NET-Framework.exe", creates a VBScript file ("run_hidden.vbs") that executes "NET-Framework.exe" hidden, creates a batch file ("run_hidden.bat") to execute the VBScript, and modifies the "Userinit" value in the Windows registry's Winlogon key to execute the batch file on startup. Finally, it starts "NET-Framework.exe" without a new window.

The script's capabilities include file download, file encryption/decryption, file manipulation, registry modification, and process execution.
